overview: Registering land and property with Land Registry, transferring ownership of registered land, protecting your property from property fraud
title: Registering land or property with Land Registry

table.body:
:england-wales:

By law, you must register all land or property in your name with Land Registry if:

+ you've bought it
+ it's been given to you
+ you've taken over the ownership from someone else (eg you've inherited a property) - this is known as 'transferring ownership'
+ you lease it and the lease was originally granted for more than 7 years

In some cases, you might also need to register land that's leased to you for less than 7 years. [Contact Land Registry](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/customer-service/enquiries "Contact Land Registry"){:rel="external"} if you aren’t sure.

Most people use a solicitor or conveyancer to register, but you can do it yourself. 

##Voluntary registration
Even if you don't have to register by law, there are benefits to doing so voluntarily:

+ it shows proof of ownership
+ it helps to [protect your land from fraud](protect-a-property-against-fraud "Protect a property against fraud")
+ it makes it easier to change ownership

You could get a discount of 25% on the registration fee if you're registering land or property voluntarily for the first time.

^[Find out if your property is registered](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/register-land/am-i-registered "Find out if your property is registered: Land Registry"){:rel="external"} by answering a few simple questions from Land Registry.^

:england-wales:

:scotland:
If your land or property is in Scotland, register it with [Registers of Scotland.](http://www.ros.gov.uk "Registers of Scotland"){:rel="external"}
:scotland:

:northern-ireland:
To register land or property in Northern Ireland, contact [Land and Property Services.](http://www.dfpni.gov.uk/lps){:rel="external"}
:northern-ireland:
table.title: When you must register

table.body:
To register your land or property for the first time, you need to download and fill out the 3 forms below. You'll need 2 copies of form DL.

$D
[Transfer of whole of registered title(s) (form TR1) (PDF, 82KB)](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/upload/documents/TR1.pdf "Form TR1:Transfer of whole of registered title(s)"){:rel="external"}
[Application for first registration (form FR1) (PDF, 82KB)](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/upload/documents/FR1.pdf "Form FR1: Application for first registration"){:rel="external"}
[List of documents (form DL) (PDF, 125KB)](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/upload/documents/DL.pdf "Form DL: List of documents"){:rel="external"}
$D

You also need to include the following:

+ a plan of where the land is
+ the original deeds and documents of title
+ the original and a copy of the lease, if you're applying to register leasehold land or property
+ results of your searches from the Land Charges Department - [download form K15 (PDF, 185KB)](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/upload/documents/k15.pdf "Form K15: Application for an official search"){:rel="external"}
+ proof of identity - [download form ID1 (PDF, 62KB)](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/upload/documents/ID1.pdf "Form ID1: Certificate of identity for a private individual"){:rel="external"}
+ [download form DI (PDF, 92KB)](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/upload/documents/DI.pdf "Form DI: Disclosable overriding interests"){:rel="external"} if you're declaring ‘overriding interests’
+ a Land Transaction Return certificate if you've paid Stamp Duty Land Tax, issued by HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)
+ the [registration fee](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/fees/online-calculator "Online fee calculator"){:rel="external"} - this depends on how much your property is worth and whether your registration is compulsory or voluntary

If any of the original deeds are missing, [contact Land Registry](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/customer-service/enquiries "Contact Land Registry"){:rel="external"} for advice.

^Use [Land Registry’s office finder](http://www.landreg.gov.uk/about-us/office-finder "Land Registry office finder"){:rel="external"} to find out where to send your forms.^

*[HM]: Her Majesty's

To register transfer of ownership, download and fill out [form AP1 (PDF, 162KB)](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/upload/documents/AP1.pdf "Form AP1: Application to change the register"){:rel="external"} and either of the forms below.

If you're transferring a whole registered title:

$D
[Download 'Transfer of whole of registered title(s) (form TR1)' (PDF, 82KB)](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/upload/documents/TR1.pdf "Form TR1: Transfer of whole of registered title(s)"){:rel="external"} 
$D

If you're transferring part of a registered title:

$D
[Download 'Transfer of part of registered title(s) (form TP1)' (PDF, 101KB)](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/upload/documents/TP1.pdf "Form TP1: Transfer of part of registered title(s)"){:rel="external"}
$D

Use [Land Registry’s office finder](http://www.landreg.gov.uk/about-us/office-finder "Land Registry office finder"){:rel="external"} to find out where to send your forms.
table.title: Transfer ownership

table.body:
There are several things you can do to protect your property from fraud.

##Register your property
Not all properties are registered, as registration hasn't always been compulsory. [Registering](register-for-the-first-time "Register for the first time") your property:

+ provides an up-to-date official record of who owns the land
+ gives you greater security
+ means you might be able to get compensation from Land Registry if you suffer a financial loss because of fraud

##Keep your details up-to-date
If you have property registered with Land Registry, you have to provide an 'address for service'. Land Registry will use this to contact you.

Updating your contact details is free and helps make sure you get important communications. To do this, download ['Keep your contact details up-to-date' (PDF, 394KB)](http://www1.landregistry.gov.uk/upload/documents/updating_contact_form.pdf "Keep your contact details up-to-date: Land Registry"){:rel="external"} from Land Registry.

You can have up to 3 addresses. For example:

+ an address where you’re living now
+ an email address
+ an address abroad

^If you register more than 1 address, you're more likely to find out if Land Registry receives a fraudulent application about your property.^

##Have a 'care of' address
You can ask your legal adviser if they’ll act as a 'care of’ address. This means any letters Land Registry sends to you will also be sent to them.

##Put a restriction on your title
A restriction limits the powers of the registered owner to deal with or dispose of a property (eg sell it or use it to raise a mortgage). This could help stop someone forging your signature on a deed to try to defraud you.

$E
**Example:** If you have an ‘LL’ restriction on your title, somebody can only register the sale or mortgage of the property if a professional conveyancer certifies that they're the owner.
$E

Speak to your legal adviser about putting a restriction on the title.

## When you're most at risk from property fraud
You're more likely to be at risk if:

- your property’s mortgage has been paid off
- your property is empty or you're letting it
- you're abroad, absent, infirm or in a home

^If you're worried you may already be the victim of property fraud, [contact Land Registry](http://www.landreg.gov.uk/about-us/office-finder "Find your nearest Land Registry office"){:rel="external"} immediately. You should also get [legal advice](http://legaladviserfinder.justice.gov.uk/AdviserSearch.do "Contact a legal adviser"){:rel="external"} and [contact the police.](http://www.police.uk/ "Contact the police"){:rel="external"}^
table.title: Protect a property against fraud
